item.title: C++ important question
item.dc:creator: @Hash1 Hash1
item.description:
@Hash1 wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:10, topic:478019”]This is also a design preference. Personally, I prefer main to do as little as possible. I’d rather shift the main execution thread over to using “my functions” versus main, which is sort of an “out-of-the-program” function. That’s my take on it, anyway.

Getting into larger applications, this becomes easier to do. For example, if I’ writing a game, then the main function is going to handle initializing the core objects and then invoking their initialization methods, then passing on its execution to the main game loop, or block until the main game loop ends (if another thread is created for it instead, etc). Main just does pre-initialization and then starts the application. Most of the remaining work is done elsewhere.[/quote]

That’s exactly what I did, but she explained me why she wanted that. She wants that the students learn the basics and all, but I told her that I learned OOP before with Java and she said that’s why it’s hard for me.

item.title: C++ important question
item.dc:creator: @Hash1 Hash1
item.description:
@Hash1 wrote:

At school, we’re doing programs using the C++ programming language, but my teacher always says something that I’m not sure about. Here it is:

She wants us to do functions, as usual for a good program, but what she says is that I shouldn’t put everything in the functions. She wants me to call the functions in the main, like this:

[code]
int main()
{
int number;

call function here

cin >> number;

if (number == 1)
call this function
else if (number == 2)
call other function
else
call another function

etc etc…

return 0;
}[/code]

instead of

[code]
int main() {

call function here and everything handled in functions instead of main

return 0;
}[/code]

Do you think she’s right, and if yes, why?
